title: Can an average student get into the IIMs? - Quora

response.answer_text: The answer to it can differ vastly based on one's definition of 'an average student.'  In a majority of cases, an average student is referred to as someone with an average academic background. Surely, there are some IIMs that take into account excellent academic background both at school and college level. But there are other B-schools like IIM Lucknow and the new IIMs that have put into place eligibility criteria that do not require their students be nerds. Let us understand that ALL those who make it to IIMs are NOT: Born IntelligentIITians90 or 80 percentage plus overall in X, XII, Graduation, (despite the stringent academic oriented selection criteria)Voracious readers during whole of their lifeExceptional with calculation or mathematical skills. IIM Indore is one college which is brutal as far as past academics is concerned. It places a whopping 76% weightage on 10th and 12th std. Rest assured, if you have a 70% in 10th or 12th, IIM Indore will not be calling you even if you score 100 percentile. IIM Bangalore is another IIM which values academics a lot. However, it is still a bit balanced as compared to IIM Indore. IIM Bangalore, like Indore, does not give points for academic diversity. It values work-ex quite a bit, which can be seen from their student base as well. Class 10th - 20%, Class 12th - 10%, Graduation - 20%. IIM Calcutta gives 40% weightage to past academics ( both class 10th and 12th having 20%) and 56% weightage to CAT. For any score above 80%, you get full points in the academic category. Basically, the competition boils down to higher CAT percentile. IIM Ahmedabad gives 30% weightage to academics (Class 10th, Class 12th and Graduation all having 10%). However, the competition is so cut-throat, you might end up losing your seat with an 80% in 1 or 2 of the 3 years. Surprisingly, IIM Ahmedabad gives absolutely zero weightage to work experience. It values a fresher and an investment banker with 3 years work experience equally, definitely raising some eye-brows. In my opinion, IIM Lucknow has one of the best shortlisting criteria. It gives 20% weightage to past academics (Class 10th and Graduation 10% each), 60% to CAT, 10% to work-ex and 10% to diversity. It covers all bases. Apart from the obvious inclination towards CAT, IIM Lucknow values both academics and work-ex to a reasonable extent. The other IIMs may not give you another chance at redemption, but IIM Kozhikode will. It gives 20% weightage to 12th and that too, full marks if you score above 80%. So – Academics and average profile is NOT a barrier to make it to IIMs. To be able to get into IIMs you need to be among the top students who qualify the CAT entrance exam and for that good preparation and confidence is the key. Following action plan is suggested: Identify your natural strength area – that can be Quant or Verbal or NONE (it is fine to have none)Are fundamentals clear – Fundamentals is knowing where you can use a concept and what are the limitations?For example – What will be the LCM of 10, 20 and minus 30?Or, Can I call (-2) (minus 2) an even integer? Can I use unitary method in directly proportional relations or inversely proportions relations?Enroll with the Coaching / Mock Test Series that suits your need the best. Working Professionals should prefer Online CAT Coaching with real time interactive classes to take care of their time management and should avoid weekend’s long offline classes. Freshers can opt for either Offline or Online Coaching.Have 1-3 mentors guiding you throughoutMore than the quantity of mocks, focus on analysis of mocks and using the outcome of analysis, to improve on regular basisDo not get bogged down by what others are saying about your preparation – rather just focus on your plan and how to improve continuously so that you maximize your score on D-DayAvoid silly mistakes On an average, how many questions do you get wrong because you read ‘must’ at the place of ‘can’? Many a time, we skip the words, and that results in error.Wrong assumptions – You went ahead with only one set of values to check your answer, without realizing that there could be another possibility. For example, if length of a rectangle is increased by 20%, and breadth is increased by 10%, what is the percentage change in perimeter?Did you get 15% or 16.66%?Answer is – cannot be determined because percentage is not a function of addition or subtraction. Perimeter has a plus sign in it.Practice is the key Once you have taken care of the above points, then comes the need of Practice. This one is most significant after the above points. Remember even Kohli goes for a net practice before every match and ensures he improves atleast 0.1% after every such session. It’s not that he is not aware of a batting type, but practice keeps him alert and ensures he is continuously improving.Practice Quality Questions which are NON-REPETITIVE in natureStart reading a good newspaper / non- fiction novels. This will help you get a good hold in RC. In any case, questions from Verbal Logic like Para Jumble and CR are quite logical in nature, and you can learn the tactics to solve those questions easily.Go through the conceptsIf you find yourself average in an area it means (in most of the cases) that you have NOT solved similar questions in your life. It is your time – to go through the concepts and solve the questions – that will take you to higher levels of intelligence. Hope it will help, thanks..

No! (If the student is average throughout the life) I was using the word ‘average’ in one of my previous answers. Before using it, I quickly googled for a definition and found that an average student is ‘consistently’ in the middle of the class. Note the word consistently. Since getting into IIMs is for a class which has millions of students, the average student is probably a 6 pointer. Well, 15% of IIM Calcutta Batch of 2019 are 6 pointers or worse. So, yes, IIM Calcutta has a lot of average students considering only academics. But, an average student cannot make it to IIM Calcutta. Paradox? Average in CAT according to the definition of average is 50 Percentile. A student with 50 %ile in CAT is most likely not getting a call from IIM Calcutta for an interview. So, an average student (consistently average student) cannot make it to IIM Calcutta. I understand that I did not answer your question directly. So, here is the thing If you already screwed your 10th, 12th, and Grad academics, the chances of making it to IIMs is difficult. But then, 15% of the batch at IIM Calcutta are exceptions. But how can a set of 60 students be called ‘exception’? You get the point!All the 6 pointers at IIM Calcutta cracked an exam called CAT. Probably excelled during the Personal Interview. They were not average there!To conclude, An average student can make it if (s)he is not consistently average. The difficulty of making it to an IIM increases with consistency in being average. But again, if (s)he is exceptional in CAT and aces the Personal Interview, (s)he can make it! A friend of mine who was a 5 pointer at college got 99.99 %ile in CAT 2016 and made it to IIM Ahmedabad, Class of 2019.

Story of an average IIT-IIM aspirant. He is the average student of an average engineering college. He is the one, who has been feeling remorse for not making it to IIT. Even if he had never wanted to go into an IIT, the feeling of letting down his parents makes him curse himself for the next four years of his college. The rest of the time is wasted over booze, fag, grass and passing marks. The reality of life struck him in the final year, when he ends up with a job of an average salary. But, now anyways he doesn't have an option! He never gave a thought about his future! The only future planning he had done was during the booze sessions with friends when everyone either became a future entrepreneur or a society changing politician or an IAS officer..! Anyway, registering for CAT seems a good idea at that time. Atleast, let's get the feel of what CAT is like! Because, UPSC is too risky.... and maybe because he had already failed once to make it to IITs, he thought he may never be able to tackle an exam like UPSC anyway..!! Wait..!! What about the CAT  'videshi' equivalents GMAT and GRE?? Going abroad is a distant dream; moreover leaving parents behind in India would not be a good idea after all.He takes CAT, ends up nowhere and joins the average-paying job which he had secured on campus placements. Year after year he appears for CAT, hoping to storm into IIMs and hoping to make his under-graduation failure story into a post-graduation success story..!!! The truth hits him like an iron anvil after three cat attempts. He cannot secure an IIM call, his professional life is moving into a rat race of thousands of underachievers like him. Finally, the only saving grace he has is to get into a college whose name at least people know. And then what? The story of his mediocrity never ends! Just because he is the average person who has always sought a comfort zone in life; hesitant to take bold and risky decisions. Because, he had failed once, he never really believes in himself that he can make big in life thus trapping himself in the vicious cycle of mediocrity. PS: Do you also feel the story is incomplete ? Well, it is ! But the author wont complete it. The story would be completed by the average guy himself... Let's see where does he wants to take it   :)  Source - www.pagalguy.com

Hello all aspirants There is minimum criteria for getting admission in MBA is that you should have Min 50%(percent )in your graduation along with other acedmics. then only you can apply for CAT,you should focus on your study in a proper way because all IIMs not giving weightage to acedmics. So if you are dreaming to be an IIM student you should score in CAT more than 99.xx percentile to getting calls from IIMs, if your acedmics is low. In a majority of cases, an average student is referred to as someone with an average academic background. Surely, there are some IIMs that take into account excellent academic background both at school and college level. But there are other B-schools like IIM Lucknow that have put into place eligibility criteria that do not require their students be nerds. Thus, indicating that IIMs are not always on the lookout for students with consistently rising academic performance graphs in the past. And while CAT most certainly is one of the toughest management entrance exams in the country, it's not an impossible exam to crack. The key to cracking CAT is consistent efforts, practice and determination. Let's consider another rumor that has become consistent with the CAT exam. Majority of the people are of the view that candidates from an engineering background have an edge over candidates from the commerce or arts background. Unfortunately, that's just a misinterpretation of the fact that the majority of the students appearing for CAT are engineers thus increasing their probability of getting selected into top institutes. This, however, by no means indicates that non-engineering students do not make it to the IIMs. And to mention the fact the over the last few years most of the IIMs have induced a policy where non-engineering students are given additional points while short listing of candidates profiles. IIMs have been implementing new criteria for short listing of students to ensure that no one category of students gets an added advantage. These new policies have been put in place to ensure that students from diverse background make it to the IIMs. Weightage of acedmics in IIMs- IIM: Ahmedabad 30% IIM Bangalore 50% IIM: Calcutta 40% IIM: Lucknow 20% IIM: Indore 76% IIM: Kozhikode 15% IIM: Kashipur Nil IIM: Raipur Nil IIM: Ranchi Nil IIM: Rohtak Nil IIM: Tiruchirappalli Nil IIM: Udaipur Nil IIM Amritsar Not announced IIM Bodh Gaya Not announced IIM Nagpur Not announced IIM: Sambalpur Nil IIM: Sirmaur Nil IIM: Visakhapatnam 50% IIM: Jammu Nil Every year lakhs of students appear for the CAT entrance exam. However, it's only a small percentage of these students who are really serious about the exam. Most of the other candidates just appear for the CAT exam like they do for any other entrance exam. So, if someone is serious about getting into IIMs they should look at that small percentage of students as their competitor. The major difference that can be seen between the students who managed to qualify CAT as the toppers and someone who just barely managed to make it past the mark is their ability to process the given information in a limited time period. Cracking the CAT is no herculean task, any candidate can do it if they were to do it without the time restriction. For someone appearing in the CAT exam, the confidence is the key. To be able to get into IIMs you need to be among the top students who qualify the CAT entrance exam and for that good preparation is the key. So, some of the preparation tips that you must keep in mind while preparing for the CAT are: Identify your strengths and weakness and practice the areas that you are weak in.Make sure that your concepts are clear.Focus more on accuracy and try to avoid making silly mistakesRemember that practice is the key to cracking the exam.Thanks and best of luck for upcoming exams.If you like my answer please upvote.

The one question that bugs most of the CAT aspirants is, 'Can an average student get into IIMs?' And the answer to it can differ vastly based on one's definition of 'an average student.' In a majority of cases, an average student is referred to as someone with an average academic background. Surely, there are some IIMs that take into account excellent academic background both at school and college level. But there are other B-schools like IIM Lucknow that have put into place eligibility criteria that do not require their students be nerds. Thus, indicating that IIMs are not always on the lookout for students with consistently rising academic performance graphs in the past. And while CAT most certainly is one of the toughest management entrance exams in the country, it's not an impossible exam to crack. The key to cracking CAT is consistent efforts, practice and determination. Every year lakhs of students appear for the CAT entrance exam. However, it's only a small percentage of these students who are really serious about the exam. Most of the other candidates just appear for the CAT exam like they do for any other entrance exam. So, if someone is serious about getting into IIMs they should look at that small percentage of students as their competitor. The major difference that can be seen between the students who managed to qualify CAT as the toppers and someone who just barely managed to make it past the mark is their ability to process the given information in a limited time period. Cracking the CAT is not a herculean task, any candidate can do it if they were to do it without the time restriction. For someone appearing in the CAT exam, the confidence is the key. To be able to get into IIMs you need to be among the top students who qualify the CAT entrance exam and for that good preparation is the key. So, some of the preparation tips that you must keep in mind while preparing for the CAT are: Identify your strengths and weakness and practice the areas that you are weak in.Make sure that your concepts are clear.Focus more on accuracy and try to avoid making silly mistakesRemember that practice is the key to cracking the exam

Let me answer this question based on the contemporary IIM Admission criteria. Intelligent Vs Average Well, in terms of IIMs and if we see the criteria of admission to IIMs, intelligent person is no more the one who has a good aptitude, but a person who has a strong academic profile. So, if you have a good aptitude but not so good academics, in contemporary era of IIM Selection Criteria, you may fall into the category of Average. Let us understand that ALL those who make it to IIMs are NOT: (a) Born Intelligent (b) IITians (c) 90 or 80 percentage plus overall in X, XII, Graduation, (despite the stringent academic oriented selection criteria) (d) Voracious readers during whole of their life, (f) Exceptional with calculation or mathematical skills. Thus, if you have a good aptitude where you can score high despite being the so called Average student by some nerds out there; you can make it to the top IIMs, especially IIM Calcutta, IIM Indore, IIM Lucknow are certainly in the list. Only IIM where an average student may not be able to make the cut is IIM Bangalore. So, why to get bogged down just because of one IIM? You still have 12 IIMs to work for and 5 old IIMs, with 3 old IIMs still providing an almost level playing field. So - Academics and average profile is NOT a barrier to make it to IIMs. No one can stop you from winning, if you are determined and confidentStatistically speaking Zero marks in CAT is equivalent to 55 percentile on an average over last 10 years. That means almost 55% of total aspirants got zero marks or negative marks. Please NOTE it is primarily because they believed they cannot and won’t get into IIMs since initial days of their preparation. Would you like MSD to hold the captaincy in the next World Cup Cricket if he says on day 1 that we are not going to win World Cup? Apply the same yardstick for yourself too. I have written a full fledged article on this, along with a Motivational Video - Please check it out HERE, in case you want to read more detailed information on the same. Cheers, Varun Saxena Founder and CEO Career Anna / India’s First end to end Online Learning Platform www.careeranna.com

No one can define an average student. Average person is the person who tags himself 'average' as an excuse for not undertaking a job/task which he assumes to be difficult/ impossible/out of his/her comfort zone without even trying it. What can an average student do? Nothing. One can do nothing unless one shreds the tag of average from oneself and starts working towards one’s goals with dedication. Once ready to work out of comfort zone, there is no stopping to become more than average.  Image source - Google Don't believe it, have a look at the below real-life examples. In September, 1950, a boy was born to a family of grocers in Mehsana district, Gujarat. His family belonged to oil-presser community, which is categorised as an OBC in India. He worked at Vadnagar railway station with his father and later with his brother near a bus terminus. He completed his higher education in 1967, where a teacher described him as anaverage student. This average student went on to become one of the most influential people in world and Prime Minister of largest democratic country, India with a landslide victory in 2014.  Still not sure... Have a look at one more. In October, 1931; a child is born in the house of a boat owner and imam of a local mosque. In 1914, his family business of ferrying people failed and the family fortune and properties were lost over time. At an early age, he sold newspapers to supplement his family's income. He had average grades in school but was described as a bright student. This small town boat owner's son with average grades with his passion for knowledge and dedication for Physics is been regarded as Missile Man, People's President of India.  Still not convinced.. Many more real-life examples are present around for inspiration. Now to the CAT exam. The syllabus of CAT exam is school level Maths and English. So it would be fair to say that it does not require an Einstein brain to crack it. CAT is for everyone. Anyone can learn the concepts, what this exam tests is the application of concepts, time management, strategy, alertness, stress management, ability to adapt to changes, dedication and hard work you have put in for the test and many more attributes. In short, CAT is a really a Test of Aptitude of Common man. Self- motivate yourself and get started. Good Luck for CAT.

For admissions to IIMs there is a criteria which involves different things. This includes your CAT score, academic record, work ex, extra curricular activities. So academic record is part of the whole. You might have a average academic record because of any of the following reasons: Firstly, cause maybe you just didn't have interest in studies and thus wasted your time in other nonproductive activities.The other, may be cause you really worked very hard and gave your best but still couldn't get a good academic standing.Another reason might be cause you had been following your passion or found some side project. Like you may be spending more time in a particular area of interest and have thus developed a great hold over it.For the first and second you can't give any excuse and all you can do is focus on other aspects of the application, like your CAT score, work ex etc.If it is the third one, then you would benefit a bit cause in the interview it matters and the interviewers will definitely ask the reason for the average score and then you will have the reason to show for it. As you don't have a say in the criteria set by IIMs, the average academic record will affect you. But, you can still concentrate on other aspects. Work ex: Try to apply to the IIMs only after a year's of experience cause this will add to your resume. CAT score: This thing is definitely in your hand and has a lot of weightage for getting called. So, I would recommend that you start preparing for it early and take a mock every week after you have done the preparation. Extra curricular: Do have something to show on your resume outside of your studies. This shows that you can manage different things at the same time.

Yes an average student can get into IIMs For getting admission into the Indian Institue of Management you have to give and entrance exam CAT. CAT is a Common Admission Test which is generally conducted in last week of November for admission into IIM's In this exam, there are three sections which are:- 1.Verbal Reading Comprehension 2.Data Interpretation & Logical Reasoning 3. Quantitative Ability There are 34 questions on each Verbal Reading comprehension and Quantitative Ability and 32 questions on Data Interpretation & Logical Reasoning. The marking scheme in the CAT exam is given below You get +3 marks for every correct answer in Objective type question.1 mark is deducted for every incorrect answer in Objective type question.You get a 0 for every objective type question that you skip in the exam.So, the key lesson is that you should not blindly guess answers in CAT. It can harm your overall score because of the negative marking in the objective questions. For getting admission into IIM's one needs to get above 90 percentile. It may look hard at first but it is not impossible to get. With proper guidance and regular study one can achieve more than 90 percentile in CAT exam One needs to study 3–4 hours daily. Practice is a must to get a good percentile in CAT. More you practice more marks you will get in the exam. I also suggest you join various online test series and give as many mock tests as possible. It will help in assessing your efforts from time to time. Many people say that CAT is hard. So yes it is hard for the people who don't try. And if you try nothing is impossible. So if you want to crack the CAT. Just start preparing, keep your mind away from negative things, always keep a positive attitude.  Visit Proton Training Solutions for more information

first of all , there is nothing like average or brilliant  The unnecessary prejudices that people have kept about themselves have made them limited in their capacity and barred them from making the ordinary to extraordinary and from impossible to possible. the only difference between an average and brilliant is their capacity to practice and hardwork. drive home the point that you cannot achieve anything brilliant by being average. I mean to say unless you practice and work hard you cannot achieve the brilliant, there is no short cut to your goal , the brilliant student is the one who has worked hard and the day an average will work hard he will to be as much brilliant to achieve his/her goal. Don’t compare your chapter 1 with someone’s chapter 20 , you never know what struggles they suffered during their chapter 1. so start your own journey towards your goal from today itself set up your task schedule and stick to it and you will definitely see results , and get a mentor to guide you. trust me the brilliant students too do the sqme or they have done the same when they were average. following are the points which will enhance your test taking ability if you are already preparing for CAT: 1. Improving and strengthening fundamentals (this should be ending by now, time wise)2. Start to build test stamina and techniques3. Take tests in simulated conditions and do a thorough analysis for improvements. How to eliminate choices, shorter cuts for answering, how to select or skip a question are important too. Find out where you are not putting enough emphasis among these three areas. Work with focus. Do feel free to rite back if needed. do upvote if you liked it

OF COURSE YES! But only when you let go of the very thought that you’re an average person. When you think lowly of yourself, you are not able to put all of your efforts. Not putting all of your efforts mean lacking somewhere which will automatically get reflected to your performance and hence turning you into an average student that you are not. This thought is basically reducing your potential. So, keep such thoughts aside and focus completely on your preparation so that when . next time you give exam and get admitted to an IIM, you have a big fat smile on your face saying- I’m no average! start with making a timetable. set achievable goals.Do not try to cover so much at once. Do little by little, day by day.For reasoning you can refer to books by Arihant publications or M K Pandey’s Book – “Analytical Reasoning”For English, I’d suggest you to go for the books Arihant Publication’ s “Objective General English” by SP Bakshi or “Word Power Made Easy” book by Norman Lewis. These books are considered to be best for exam preparation.For Quantitative Aptitude Section, go for R S Agarwal – Quantitative Aptitude for Competitive exams.For GK, start reading newspaper as newspaper is the rich source of all types of news be it national, international or sports.Follow good websites such as StudyBuzz that will guide you stepwise in preparation through their interactive videos and motivational approach.Attempt mock tests and analyse yourself.

Everyone was an average at some point and maybe some still are. IIMs make a best out of a person. Such prestigious institutions would not be constituted by averafe students. Only those who tried to change the definition of average in their personality and academics would be selected in IIMs. The process of getting into IIM is indeed exhaustive, if you realise the oppourtunity early, the right year and time to spend at in something, so it’s an average student trying his BEST and doing hardwork to get into an IIM. You need to reset, learn and unlearn many things to enter into the corporate world. The life is hectic, something to cope up with if an average student aspires to be a part of it. You need to realise where you are in your life right now. You can use studybuzz/cracku/hitsbulleye to know what level of preparation and personality changes an average student requires. Do not have the remorse of being average. Also, if your academics have been average, you need a huge great push to actually make it to great instituions. As I said, the core of IIM institutions are its extraordinary and hardworking people. One change always change and its never too late for a change. Mocks can give you assesment of your current level. The competition is really huge in India for a few number of seats for these prestigious institutions and the perks later associated with it are something to look for as a future goal investment, something to reply upon, changing or being a part of your life.

Now, if you have the notion that only those students can enter the IIMs who happen to have 95% marks in 10th and 12th and 85% marks in their graduation, then fortunately you are wrong. Either that or those who have incredible extra curricular or job experience in their CVs. Now, keep in mind that around 3500+ students take admission in IIMs every year, so it is obvious that some “average” students make it to an IIM. Moreover, being average depends on your perception. A student at IIM may not be able to compete with his peers (hence branded average) but still the whole country would kill for his seat (hence hailed as extraordinary). My suggestion to you is that forget the whole average thing and just prepare well for CAT and interviews. Hope it helps :) P.S. People with less than 60% marks in graduation have made it to IIM Rohtak this year.

Average is a very subjective term. Someone with 80% may be below average in the TN board, but a topper in Bihar or Rajasthan. Ditto for engineering colleges. There is no comparison between a 60% in Anna University and in Pune University. This is the reason we have standardised exams like the JEE for engineering, NEET for medical and CAT for management, which gives every candidate an equal opportunity to score marks and get into an institute of their choice. If you can manage a 99.5+ overall percentile score in the CAT, with 98+ in the sectionals, there is a very good chance of getting calls from the IIMs, even the older ones. After that, your performance in the interview will decide whether you get admission or not. There is some weightage given to acads and work experience, but the PI and CAT scores have a higher weightage in the final admission decision. So, don't worry about the past, because there is nothing you can do about it. Look at the future optimistically, and do your best.

IIMs is a broad term covering group of 20 institutions, with nearly eachone with their own criteria for selection. Now they categorize students based on their acads , something as this  Now for each candidate CAT cutoffs are gonna be different  So you can see that if you are in category C the you would have to top CAT to be in the shortlist, now this is only for A,B, C next category of IIMs those are L,K and I are comparatively easy to get into with average acads, same hold true for new IIMs. As for my advise, “Yesterday is history,tomorrow is a mystery, and today is a gift... that's why they call it present” Give your best to CAT…

First of all we have to be very clear about the definition of “Average Student”. If compared to Einstein, most of the scientists are average. That doesn't mean they can't contribute to the field of science or make an amazing discovery. I am guessing from your question that by average student here you mean someone from an average college with average academics throughout​ his academic career. If that is true, it becomes a little difficult to get into IIM's. But it's not impossible. With a very good CAT score and good performance on the other rounds, one can make it to IIM's. Though it will be extremely difficult to make it to the older IIM's, new ones can definitely be cracked. However i would advise you not to think about all this as of now and to put all your energy and focus towards the preparation. All the best..;)

NO  If you are Average in AmbitionIf you are Average in PersistentIf you are Average in Getting out of your Comfort ZoneIf you are Average in Going Extra MileIf you are Average in Willingness to Explore ConceptsIf you are Average in Finding what Works for You.If you are Average in Believing You!

Yes! If one has the right aptitude while appearing for the various MBA entrance exams, he/she can surely crack the exam. The CAT exam, in general, is not tough, but it’s the competition that makes it more challenging to crack. You need to have your basics clear, vocabulary has to be really good, and a lot of questions from the various topics have to be practiced on a regular basis. Then give as many mocks(sectional & Mock CATs), and analyze them properly. So, belling the CAT is not that difficult. But, the IIM’s not just consider your CAT score, but also your overall profile. So if you’re academic scores are not great(i.e. say >60%), then getting a call from the old IIM’s will be difficult for you, but not impossible. If you are eyeing to get into the new IIM’s, then it is very much possible, as they consider mainly your CAT score and how you’ve performed in the interviews. So for now, just focus on scoring well in CAT and give it your best shot. All the best!

No You need to work harder than averageYou need to focus more than averageYou need to sacrifice more than averageYou need to manage better than averageYou need to perform better than averageGetting into a good IIM is not something you can do by doing what an average student does. If you mean “average” profile, do the above and you won’t be average anymore, nothing can stop you.

Yes. First of all you don't have to downvote yourself on being an average student. We are never perfect. You can get into the IIM'S with extraordinary hard work and bound determination towards your goal. You just have to plan your studies according to your strengths and weaknesses. You have to work with utmost sincerity. It all ends up to how motivated you are towards your goal. Hard work, sincerity and time management are the things you need to persue, but your own undying will to make your objective true will need some emotional stability and motivation. So work accordingly. Hope this helps. All the best :)

You can, and you should aim for it- There is one question to ask yourself. Why is it that you consider yourself an average student ? Is it because your academic credentials doesn't prove you to be a 90 or 80 percentiler, is this is the case- you might want to research a little and find out that percentages aren't the only criteria to get selected in an IIM. I did a quick google search and got to know why considering to get into IIM isn't strange even if you have lower percentages than the top percentilers. This isn't the first hand information but surely makes sense- here is the first link that appears for the Google search Can An Average Student Get Admission to an IIM? Look for more such articles to motivate yourself!

First of all, you need to remove that notion from your mind that only students with above 90% marks throughout their career land into IIMs. Also every year a lot of students make into IIMs who are in the 70s throughout their career (that’s what average means to me) so you need to introspect what is average to you. Also, it is true that if you have completely screwed your Xth, XIIth, and Graduation then it might be a bit difficult. So, forget all these and focus on CAT as I know people who were below average in their career when it came to academics but aced the exam and personal interviews and got through IIMs. PS: I would suggest working on your CV also while you prepare.
I talked to a guy named Aman Kumar, on pagalguy, a general category student with following academicsX : 71XII : 66UG : 8.3CAT 14 : 99.97 HE MADE IT TO IIMA.

No chance if you are an Engineer and a general category. You might have chances in IIM C , But 0% chances in IIM A and IIM B , So why be afraid? Start preparing for best MBA college in India that is ISB (not a single IIM is among Top 30 MBA colleges in world but ISB is present). Getting into ISB is little easier if you have great experience in a particular field. (But if you are a reserved student (here ST,SC and others) then just go in exam Hall write you name and come back don't mark any options you would get a call from IIM and easily be selected) since 50% of students scores -ve score and added to that for reserved people in many IIMs cutoff is generally below 50%).

There has never been a precise measurement of the term average in terms of skills and knowledge and it varies from person to person. You can never gauge what an average student would be for the other guy standing beside you in the queue. So, if you ask me personally, I am an average guy and presently I am in IIM Rohtak. I believe that anyone can get into an IIM by fulfiling the basic criteria mentioned by individual IIMs. All it takes is the zeal and determination along with commitment towards your goal. If you are able to stick to it, the sail will be smooth and glorious. You just need to believe in yourself and put the right step ahead on a positive note.
Always remember,  Hardwork can definitely beat talent when talent doesn't work hard.

How average? If by average, you mean that you have a 90+ in 10th and 12th and 78+ percentage in your UG(Engineering), then YES! You can get into the IIMs. Anything lesser in any of the above will hamper your chances of shortlist unless you have an exceptionally high CAT percentile, a category or a diversity factor.

Management aspirants, who have already appeared for the Common Admission Test, will spend the rest of the weeks preparing for the Group Discussion(GD) and Personal Interview rounds.  Hi GD requires 3 things 1. Good all round knowledge of various issues esp current affairs. Not just knowing facts, but understanding and using facts to make logical arguments 2. Good guidance regarding GD evaluation, do's and dont's etc from an experienced trainer 3. Sufficient practice at least 7-8 sessions before the actual GD. After having a CAT score card of 98% it that important to have an excellent academic background to get through an IIM. An aspirant with an average or below average academic background after cracking CAT well can't get through IIM. XAT and SNAP are the most popular other exam, each having 4-6 good Bschools that you can apply for. SNAP is a relatively easy high scoring paper XAT is a tough, logic driven paper.

The cutoffs need to be cleared - acads percentages, CAT scores etc. Apart from that, its about what you want to do, rather than what you have done till now. Have clarity on why do you want to get into IIM, what will you do in those two years and how will it impact your future life. Prepare for your interviews, WAT etc. Think Through & Drill Down on the 5Ws. Do mock interviews, talk to people, talk to alumni, take help. And ofcourse, there a million other things that you can do apart from getting into IIMs - but thats another story. The two years at IIMs are life changing, so if you are inclined towards it, go for it!

My take on this, Yes you can definitely get into an IIM. but if its the case with A or B or C... I'm not sure. According to last years statistics, the academic cutoffs were high for A and B, but you have a higher probability for C. If you can substantiate your average academic scores with high CAT percentile and higher GDPI/WATPI scores then you can enter any of the IIMs. Good luck!!

Possibility: YesWhy not.  If you clear cutoffs and the interview, there is no reason why you can't get in. Probability: Low One look at IIM's past admission stats is enough to drive home the point that it is extremely hard to get in.  If past performance is an indicator of future potential, you would have to work extremely hard and do much better that you have done in the past to get in.
